column1: Q-Zar of Tampa Bay is the premium place to play the most top-of-the-line laser tag in Tampa Bay as well as having an arcade and a pizza parlor.
This location houses a DDR SuperNOVAAC located on the left once you pass the entrance.
Many panels require a far amount of force (Tested by a 140 lb pretty hard stepping player) and bouncing on freeze notes (without letting go) can lose the freeze.
Monitor inside cab is either replaced and too large or needs to be re-calibrated as it cuts off the health bar.
Bar grips are replaced with white duct tape. (Surprisingly effective and comfortable)
Very annoying glare from overhead light. (More prominent on shorter players)
Left Right and Select buttons on cab are replaced with spare parts from other machines.
Overall SuperNova machine quality is acceptable.
Many quirks but I managed to complete some difficult songs without too much hatred for the machine.
[Update 7/17/17] After 1 year the machine is in the exact same condition it was in as previously noted which indicated no desire to fix any of the problems.

column1: For OVER 30 years we have provided the  Northern New Jersey area with the best in  family entertainment.
Please come and enjoy ""The Break""  I think you will find this unusual different family fun center has everything you could ever want.

Eight On the Break was founded by Edward Montross in 1973. Ed was WAY far ahead of his time. Many years later a new generation ( me) would take his concept and run with it! The Family Fun Center was born!

The break"" was primarily a ""pool hall""  at that time but it was the very first place to have the new fangled ""TV games"". 8OTB has fuzzy wallpaper (still here from the 1970's) shag carpet and paintings on the walls.

In 1986 my company American Family Fun Centers purchased 8OTB from Mr. Montross. The late 80's saw many changes with a strong focus on video games.  It was our ability to change with the times and adopt new ideas that has kept 8OTB alive.
First came the fighting games then the dancing/music games. What ever the fad 8OTB has been on top of it.
Billiards has always been a mainstay at 8OTB and we have the least expensive rates in the tri-state area!
Well that's pretty much the story. 33 years and still going strong! Come on down play some games
column3: and finish with an hour or two playing billiards. I am sure you will leave wanting to come back

column1: Click each game for more info about them
We have special quarter nights every Monday from 6 PM to closing. All day quarter day specials on holidays
Also come check out the Street Fighter/Tekken/ Marvel VS Capcom 3 fight nights every Tuesday night starting at 8. Live streaming.

column2: the main entrance is from Hon Dori and the rear entrance from the next street over. Access is via stairs
column5: all along the right wall of the building. The game center has six floors
column6: all of the music games are on the second floor.

column1: There are drink and food vending machines and restrooms available. Game cards can be purchased from the attendants behind the counter. There are lots of restaurants and fast food shops nearby.
The game center opens early at 08:00 on weekends and holidays for non-gambling games only.

column1: You can get to this from the South Exit of Shinjuku (Not the New South Exit; if you are at Takashimaya you have gone too far)
column2: facing the Takashimaya department store; follow the street to the left and go down the stairs or escalator. The Taito is down the sidestreet to the left and it is so huge you should be able to see it immediately.  It is also very close to Shinjuku 3-chome station on the Fukutoshinsen Subway line.

probably 8/10 - along with the Redondo Fiesta and the Huntington Pro the only playable pads in Southern California right now (though I haven't tried the new Pro in SD yet)

column1: * Screen is a reasonable distance from the pads (WHAT A CONCEPT)
* Stage fail is on - no Vacuum NM for you
* You can't move the pads or the screen back - no 4x Hello William for you
* There aren't any fans by the machine - no dry pads for you
* Monitor burnout comes and goes - sometimes the screen will be crystal clear
column2: other times you'll struggle to read the arrows

column1: * The pads are set a little deep in the stage. I'm not sure this is a con per se - you can still hit notes without feeling like you're breaking your ankles (like you would at any D&B's)
column2: but these pads will punish you for attempting to doublestep. I don't really mind
column3: but if you're used to more flush pads where you can scrape and doublestep you'll have to adjust.

column1: The pads are starting to get iffy
column3: and the monitor burnout is a major issue: half the pixels glow like they're nuclear
column4: and there are so many layers of burn that you can still read a burn layer that says ""0/3 credits"" (from when the machine cost 75 cents to play) behind a burn layer that says ""0/4 credits"" behind the ACTUAL ""0/4 credits"". I asked the management to fix the pad sensors -- and even offered to supply the sensors themselves -- and got a blase response. Trouble ahead for this machine
column6: so enjoy it now before it craps out and joins the rest of the unplayable zombie Pump machines here in Southern Cali.

$2.25 arcade admission. All machines take nickels.
•This is THE hangout for local music game players. You'll find pretty much all of them here daily and on the weekends.
•All music games in this arcade (with the exception of Guitar Hero and DDR Extreme) are maintained by the local music game community Beatgamer (http://www.facebook.com/beatgamer)
•Wide selection of step charts and packs on the ITG machine
•The only IIDX machine in the entire region (next closest is in Las Vegas)
•Some classic games are frequently on freeplay.
•Games take nickels. $10 goes an extremely long way
•Music game community holds lock-ins quarterly with freeplay games
•Many of the games are out of order and are in need of repairs. Repairs are going slowly.
•Air hockey tables directly behind the ITG machine
•Did we mention the out of order games?
•Some of the staff can be a little rude

column1: From the About page on the official site
WhirlyDome brings the sport of WhirlyBall to Orlando
column3: activities and the new Bloodhound Brew Pub & Eatery – Orlando’s new local hangout.

column2: Orlando’s newest and perhaps most unique attraction located in the heart of International Drive
column3: is set to open its doors in and will introduce Orlando to the world’s first totally mechanized team sport – WhirlyBall.

column1: WhirlyBall is best described as a combination of bumper cars
column3: Jai-alai and hockey. The game is typically played 5-on-5
column4: with players piloting WhirlyBugs (high tech bumper cars) as they use a scoop to pass and shoot a plastic ball at their opponent’s goal while bumping and blocking their way around the court. Games have a referee to enforce the rules
column5: keep score and make sure all players have a great time. The game requires no prior experience – and absolutely no athletic skills at all! Already popular in Chicago
column6: Detroit and Atlanta and other cities
column7: WhirlyBall Orlando is sure to be a winner with two courts available for play.

column1: WhirlyDome visitors can also experience the sights
column2: sound and adrenaline rush of what it’s like to drive a Formula One race car. The WhirlyDome is home to the new Formula One racing simulator from Evotek Engineering – the first of its kind in the U.S. Created in Italy
column3: this simulator is modeled after the F1 simulators used by professional racing teams.

column2: where players navigate a maze of laser beams
column4: as well as the latest in Laser Tag. Guests will also find pool tables and a variety of arcade games.

column1: WhirlyDome isn’t just a place to play
column2: it’s also a place to relax and unwind while enjoying a drink
column3: lunch or dinner at Bloodhound Brew Pub & Eatery.   Bloodhound Brew is a casual pub featuring local specialty craft beers and a full menu made from scratch with both indoor and outdoor seating.

column1: WhirlyDome has multiple party rooms with complete AV capabilities and is ready to provide the food and fun for large corporate functions
column2: family reunions and everything in between.

column1: There is no admission charge at the WhirlyDome. Visitors pay only for activities that they take part in.

column1: - Dim LED lights installed in Marquee

column1: - 1/2"" thick foam floor tiles under both the cabinet and the pads

- P1 Oversensitivity in Down arrow was causing stray misfires on left and down; replaced sensor with less sensitive one
- P2 Down arrow needed some love
column2: I gave it a little bit - but as nobody comes by - I haven't had the motivation to really fix P2's pad
some old ones as well - P1's pads deep cleaned
column3: and some sensors replaced; P1 is now almost perfect!

column1: Our arcade is a great place to come and relive the excitement of the neighborhood arcade! We want to welcome families and hardcore arcade enthusiasts with regular tournaments and monthly high score challenges.

We currently boast the largest Japanese-style game center on the East Coast. Our emphasis is on 90’s arcade gaming; if you want to relive the 90’s (or experience it for the first time) you will not be disappointed!
Our games run on authentic Japanese arcade equipment and original hardware whenever possible. We keep things fresh by rotating games each month
column2: but due to space we cannot feature our entire collection at once. We apologize if the game you are looking for isn’t currently available. But don’t worry
column3: it may come back soon! What we do promise is you WILL see something you remember
column4: and a few things you never knew existed.

Primarily a bowling alley and laser strike venue the game selection here actually isn't too bad if you're looking to play some old classics on some generally well maintained machines.

Pricing on machines range from 1 to 2 dollars and most of the machines are in good working order. A lot of the older games that use CRT's actually still have their CRT's in good condition so that's a major plus.
Overall it isn't too crowded so it's worth checking out if you're in the area.
